Manuscript.SevenWordSummary: Cody and Miguel have a sleepover.
Manuscript.Label: Modern World
Manuscript.Body:
"Since you started on your first day, you haven't been drug tested. What's gonna change their mind on Monday, bro? My work never runs drug tests," he says. Gunfire cracks over the TV, flashing the empty walls with pops of color.

 "No shit, Miguel. Their corporate structure banks on baked box-boys like you. The ones that forget they're lifting crates and stocking shelves and selling printers for eight hours a day."

 "That's manager Miguel now — I order the little guys to do it. I'm a number-puncher like you now," He brags. "Oh. But except I'm actually good enough to get promoted."

 The words hit at the same time as a round-ending enemy airstrike. The bombs collapse my soldier to the dirt as the word DEFEAT brandishes across the screens, reassuring us that "we'll get them next time." But his quips hurt no more than the vibrations in the controller.

  Miguel cracks another lukewarm beer, kicking the box of the remaining 27 over to me. I put down my custom controller.

  "I get bringing over a six-pack of some IPA, maybe a 12-pack of Coors or something, but thirty?"

 He manages a straight face as his brown eyes pierce mine, wiping the suds from his scruffy lip rug. "You know, Jesus was wrong when he said 'man can't live on bread alone.' He didn't know you could drink it yet."

 "Is that right?" I laugh.

 "They've been rolling around the back of my car for a couple weeks after going to Katy's house. You know, high school Katy?"

 "No?"

  "The pregnancy scare one, with the nice—."

 "Yeah, no — I remember," I say. Her face flashes in my mind from our junior prom group. Miguel took her while I took Kei.

 "Well, I took her friend home and stole the thirty-rack since no one touched it. Those guys are all fuckin' hipsters, man, so far up their ass about IPA's and stuff, they won't drink just to get drunk anymore."

 "Coming from the guy who doesn't smoke just to get high," I tell him. "Passionate stoners are worse than drinkers. You couldn't be any more uninteresting when you're talking about 'Sour Dee' or whatever," I say.

 "Fuck off."

 He burps. I crack another warm one, and when the timer on the pre-game lobby counts to zero, I lift my controller again. But he hits me with something that isn't just a snide comeback.

 "Do you miss high school?" He asks.

 It takes me a moment to think. I haven't really considered it, though I've noticed myself staying away from those places we hung out between classes and after school. Those places have some gravity I'm afraid will get me sucked into that past, when I've worked so hard to put those good times behind me.

 "I dunno. It's like a friend you haven't seen in a while. Nice to visit every once in a while and relish in the past. But it's best for both of us if we move on, you know?"

 He drops the controller into his lap. My thumbs dig into the sticks when I climb a ladder for a sniper nest, only to get blasted off by a camper.

 "You trying to say something?"

 "No, dude," I start. "I—"

 "You can use that losing take on Kei or Kylie all you want, but on your friend?"

 "No, of course not! No, man. You're my best friend. You-"

 "I'm messing with you, fucker," he says.

 He laughs, swigging the rest of his beer between deaths.

 He says, "I do. I mean, a part of me does. I hated high school until the end of junior year when our group really started to hang out. It's like, I never felt like I was a part of something until then. And . . . I don't know if I really felt it since."

 "Yeah. I wonder what the others are up to," I ask.

 "Kayla's having her second kid already. Another girl, I think. Her and Johnny Boy are still together."

 "I was surprised. Getting married half a year after high school? I didn't think they'd make it this far."

 "You never went to their wedding, though."

 "I was in college halfway across the country, bud," I say.

 "How about Kei?" He asks. "You were trying to get with her for a while, but you never had the cajones to do it before she graduated after our junior year."

 "I've told you before," I say. "She's at my work."

 "No shit!" He laughs. "The yellow thirst was real for you, man." He cracks another can after getting mowed down by an LMG. "Are you gonna shoot your shot? You told me you got some experience in college, right?"

 "Yeah. But I don't know..." none of those nights in college really fulfilled me. I was always missing something. "I'm not into the clubbing scene like you are."

 "All you have to do is ask! It's not like high school. Alcohol changes things. The fellas I met in college showed me all around the city. I know that shit like the front of my hand!"

 "Back. The back of your hand," I say.

 "Whatever. But we need to get you laid, now that you got this fine house. Shit, man, I wish I could afford something like this. People our age probably never will."

 "But you still live here in Hearthland Ridge," I say.

 "Paying for a studio! Like living in a fuckin' box for seventeen hundred a month," he says. "Walls so paper-thin I can hear everything. I'd rather go out and get some pussy than cuck myself to the soundtrack of someone else getting it."

 "Uh, sure," I say — sometimes I wonder if he tries to fit as many of those words as he can into a sentence.

 "But really. I'm proud of you, man," he tells me. "Really. You've worked hard and you've made it. When I was trying to work my way through our senior class, you were grinding at math and shit. You have an actual chance to get wifed up. It's not in my blood."

 "What do you mean?" I ask.

 "Well, I don't want to. I like the chase better, you know. Settling down? That's like giving up. What do you do, then? With that feeling, you know, when you have a couple rats with some chick and you know you're locked in for the next forever?"

 The feeling's all I've been able to think about since I got back here. No more regimentation. No convenient road map of class to class to graduation: now it's all just open-ended.

 "But, like, nothing against you if you're into that. Having rats can be dope."

 "Someday. Maybe. I'm just too boring, I think," I say.

 "Boring? You were the heart of our group back then, dude. You brought us together. You're good at that."

 "But nothing's forcing any of us to be together anymore," I say. "Look at how many have moved away from here. It's just you and me now, right?"

 "Kayla and John are in California. Michael went to Kansas. He likes flat woman, so I guess he wants a state that can get him off just by driving on the roads."

 The beer comes up my nose. I drop the controller and the batteries pop out. "Ugh. Fuck, man," I say, balancing the pain of carbonation in my nose with the urge to laugh, imagining Mike trying to stick his wiener in a Kansas anthill.

 Miguel says, "Maybe we'll be stuck here forever. But hey, as long as we're both here."

 "I just wish . . ." I start to say, but instead, I reach down and pop the batteries back in the controller.

 He slicks his hair back again, finishing another one. "Is it cool if I crash here? I mean, I can drive high, but not drunk."

 "Sure, man. But I don't have a cot or a sleeping bag or anything."

 "Please. I've slept on floors my whole adult life!" He gestures to the box with 23 stones left. "Now are you gonna help me finish all of them?"

 "All of them?"

 "All of them," he says. "It's Friday. I know we're old and shit now, but stay awake a little longer, like we're twelve and it's a sleepover in your parents' basement, and I'll tell you a bedtime story."

 "Oh, great. About what?"

 "One time I was playing on your Xbox when you were out of town. When you had me pet-sitting, and..."

 "I'll pass. But—" I think, as long as I'm not drinking alone, it can't hurt. What's the worst that can happen?

Manuscript.SevenWordSummary: The two drunken friends talk about life.
Manuscript.Label: Modern World
Manuscript.Body:
"No, I get what you're saying, but what do you mean?" Miguel says, slurring his words as he melts into the futon: the only piece of furniture our drunk asses could assemble. The overturned boxes are makeshift tables that keep the cans off the floor, since we're feeling too lazy to dig for a trash bag.

 I lift the can to my lips, but I don't let the poison pass the threshold. Past experience tells me that I'm toeing my limit: lost enough to let my stupid emotions leak on my face, to conjure words to try to push them down, but not enough to kneel at the porcelain throne. I know the feeling is real because the wetness on my face gives it credence, and I often think he's the only friend I've got left to listen.

 If only I could get him to.

 "How can you get it if you don't know what I mean?" I ask.

 "I get it, bro, just not what you mean." Miguel lifts the cracked smartphone above his face as he lays on the futon, thumb-scrolling through an endless barrage of ads and entertainment.

 "What I mean is that I don't feel it anymore. My life is just work, then sleep, then work, then go to sleep, but it's nothing more than that. I don't have it like you do. You always have the energy, but I don't know how you find it." The tears leak further: I can't remember the last time I was drunk enough to let them out. "But I know the time is in between there somewhere, I mean, I'm certain I could fit in anything if I tried. But I'm always just so damn tired."

 He swipes right a couple times in a dating app, still refusing to look up. "Time isn't the only thing that's too small of yours to fit." He laughs. Then the vibration from a match startles him.

 Miguel's thumb slips and he flings his phone in the air, letting out a grunt when it crashes into his nose.He jolts upright to rub the pain out, looking at me for the first time in an hour.

 "Oh, shit. You're serious."

 "Yeah, you think this is just a bit?"

 "No, of course not." He sets his phone on a cardboard box and thinks for a moment. "Why I 'feel it.' I don't know . . . I guess I just got a big family that always keeps me busy. My cousins are young, and my siblings are still in college, so I end up going to their parties and stuff."

 "So it's like college never ended for you. Never realized I'd miss it so much . . . my roommates made the damn experience," I say. It didn't matter if we were in the dorms or slumming it in an expensive renter-fixer-upper west of campus: those fuckers forced me to get out. "Most nights, when I was studying in my bedroom, nose stuck in a textbook, they'd pick the lock and barge in — shooting me with flaming Nerf darts, assaulting me with a pizza cutter, or dragging me to one of their parties."

 He takes the last swig of his seventh can. "Just like my older cousins. They show up to my house to drag me clubbing, even if I pulled a 'tenner' at work."

 "Man. If my brother was still around, I'm sure he'd be over here all the time," I say.

 "Of course. Our families had a lot of fun together: barbeques, parties at the park..." The list trails off when he crunches the can in his hands.

 "You remember those weekends in middle school when we tried to beat the Halo campaign in a single night?"

 "Yeah. And your brother would buy all those energy drinks, sneaking them downstairs for us," he says. "Oh, and the summer tent sleepovers, remember that one night you were so scared of the lightning you couldn't move, and my dad had to carry you back inside?"

 "I was stuck in the sleeping bag, so soaking wet from the rain I almost slid out of his arms," I say. We share a laugh. "Or the RV trip we took for the out-of-state Lacrosse game—when we got stuck on the side of the road. We used up all the power playing GameCube and my dad was furious!"

 He laughs. "Yeah. And we had to ask one of the families running behind to pick us up. The whole time we waited there, your dad was screaming at Triple-A, and your mom was trying to cook, but the RV tipped so far to the side that she couldn't set anything on the counter..."

 "...And all we could do was just pass the ball on the side of the road, wondering whether or not we were gonna make the game."

 "But we won that one, right?"

 "Yeah — I ripped the game-winning corner pocket."

 "Oh yeah. Their team was trash. The goalie scored on himself."

 The nostalgia can only abate the emptiness for so long. I take another swig, feeling the body high mix with the dizziness from the flat beer. Without them, the next words might not have left me.

 "But now it's just like . . . I dunno. I only know that it sucks, you know?"

 "Of course."

 "Like, I'm trying to care, but I don't. My mind doesn't want me to be happy." I nearly fall out of the folding chair when I'm talking with my arms. "We're not forced to get out there anymore. To meet new people, to keep friendships alive. All our friends are getting married or serious while we're just left behind. My parents nag me about it all the time: getting impatient since I'm the only one left that'll keep the family name going. And—" "That shit doesn't matter. That's not what it's about," Miguel says. "You just gotta do, man. You gotta do things just to do them."

 I furrow my brows. "To do what?"

 He wets his lips on a last sip before he tries at something profound.

 "The doing is what makes happiness come, when even . . . even when you're, like, not happy, and shit, you force yourself to do things, so happy shit can happen more often and shit, so you can have the chance to enjoy it," he insists.

 I'm lost without words, so he decides to muddy the waters even further.

 "You get the gist of what I'm saying? Like, you have to decide to do no matter what. Like even when you don't feel like it, you know, you do. The doing, I mean, is something you choose which gives a chance of something good. Or something, at least. You know?" I feel like I just had a seizure. "What the fuck does that even mean?"

 "I don't know, man. Maybe I'm bad at . . . no, maybe you suck at listening," he says. "I said that shit perfectly."

 I mutter to myself, trying to piece together what he said. It takes me a couple seconds. "Force yourself to engage with the world. Give happiness its best chance to come out, because it's all you can do."

 "That's exactly what I said!" He snatches another can, using the light of the TV to inspect all the dents from rolling around in his Corolla.

 "Like hell you did!" I roll my eyes.

 His verbal seizure must have made him tired. He puts the can down instead of cracking another one, and after a long yawn, he pulls the unzipped sleeping bag off the floor and wraps it around himself on the futon. "That thing goes down flat, you know," I offer. "It doesn't have to be a couch."

 "Too much effort. I've slept on worse," he says. "I gotta get to sleep so I can make it to church tomorrow."

 "And show up hungover? I doubt you'll make it through the service," I say. "But, hey, if you stay a while after, I'm sure you could catch the double-A meeting."

 He's too tired for a clap-back. He's not even scrolling his phone anymore: just sprawled there with his feet dangling over the wobbly armrest, arms tucked beneath him, his face buried into a folded towel.

 I glance at the stove. "It's only like 12:30."

 "Long day . . . leading idiots . . . feels so late," he says, turning to bury his face in the leather crevice of the couch.

 "So much for an all-nighter, huh?"

 "Nnnn," he mumbles into the towel. "Guessn't."

 "I guess we're not young anymore," I say. "We didn't even make it through half the rack."

 "Nn."

 "So are we gonna finish these?"

 No answer.

 "I said..."

 But then I give up.

Manuscript.SevenWordSummary: A slow first day ends in panic.
Manuscript.Label: Fantasy World
Manuscript.Body:
"Is that as bad as it gets? Or is this just because it's the first day?" Pax asks. "Maybe Aldrin wasn't lying. I thought we'd be at the enemy's doorstep most days, waiting for one of them to break through." He chows down on a raw potato that he withdraws from his pocket, spitting scraps with every syllable. "But this is great — a little work for as much produce as you can eat!"

 "As long as you don't get caught, you idiot," Ryder groans.

 The two hike behind us as the sky shifts to dusk, eclipsing all the light from the setting sun. I can feel slivers of potato catching in my hair. Bertram and I shiver in their shade as we struggle for footing, stumbling down the switchbacks of the southern foothills. Despite the half-baked ramblings that often get him in trouble, Pax is right this time. There wasn't a single scouting mission on the board beyond patrolling the town.

 Does it really get this easy?

 I wait until the switchback slithers east and the trail straightens, catching the fading light on my first quest form. It's stamped and scribbled with an illiterate farmer's signature, dirtied from folding by my soil-soaked fingers. Something catches my eye before we turn another corner: a small statement that the guildscribes helped the farmer write, the only part of the form scrawled in coherent letters.

 "Hah, did you see this section?" I ask Bertram. Pax and Ryder look over our heads without bending. "List the concern and how it demands the strength of the Royal Guard's Knights."

 Bertram squints, reading the two words before a laugh seizes his throat.

 Ryder reads it instead.

 "Defending vegetables."

 "From what?" Pax asks. "Hungry bellies?"

 We share a laugh.

 "If this is as hard as it gets, then this is a vacation," Pax says, showing us his large, calloused hands. "I grew up on the outer farmlands of the Capital, working fields from dawn to dusk. Every day I was strapped for time. But this was nothing."

 Bertram agrees. "Farming up here is practically a hobby with how that town in the North supplies us. They supply the whole damn capital, but shouldn't they be covered in frost?"

 I agree.

 "Most maps don't even chart the land north of the Purgatory Mountains," I say. "It should be a frozen wasteland."

 "It sure is. I used to live there, up in Blackwater," Ryder says. It's probably the first fact he's volunteered since I met him.

 "No way. I've never met someone from up there," I say.

 "Me neither," Pax says. "I guess there's no reason to leave when there's no chance to starve, right?"

 "There's no reason to leave because you can't. Not unless you spend your whole life plotting an escape."

 The words are enough to halt us.

 "An escape?" Bertram asks. "Why would you have to escape? I thought they were part of the empire. Some kind of commune of field-hands and farmers, with enough Essence to keep the climate year-round."

 "There's not enough Essence in all of Fosroth to allow that," Pax adds. "Trust me. The Capital lands are unworkable in the winter. I couldn't even use a spade on them before I left. So I can't even imagine working the lands up there."

 "That's because the lands are beneath the ground, in warm chambers brought to life by a single Mask's Divine Wish," Ryder says. "A Divine Wish granting a chamber that can feed for eternity, rife with the seeds and succulence of every plant imaginable. But it doesn't work without slaves. None of Blackwater's middling Academy recruits find out until it's too late, so they're thrust beyond the walls: not for combat, but for servitude, delving into—"

 His words cut off when a crimson glow saturates the northern hills. We're too slow to shield our eyes when a blinding light flashes from beyond the Purgatory Mountains, as if brought by Ryder's invocation.

 It barely catches our eyes as we descend the southern foothills. Any one of us could have missed it if we blinked at the wrong time. But before we can second-guess this shared experience — held as a glow in our retinas when we close our eyes — we find the faintest column of crimson light stretching skyward, like a glowing thread tethering our world of Fosroth to the stars.

 It fades like lightning before we have the time to speak its presence. An eerie silence overshadows the town. The wind withdraws with bated breath. The crickets refuse to rub their wings. But to us — a naive band of knights that only know battle through secondhand stories — it's the truest evidence of a war we've gotten yet, and it runs my skin with gooseflesh.

 Our pace hastens down the treacherous trail. The trembling words fill every inch of impedance that keeps us from an outright sprint.

 "I thought the war was contained to the east, not the north! How would they even get around that far?" Paxton huffs.

 "It'd be almost impossible for the enemy to take Blackwater," Ryder says.

 "But the column was red!" Bertram says. "There's surely a Mask up there that just did something. It might have even been their Divine Wish..."

 "You mean they just jettisoned all their Essence?" I ask. Essence on the order of the Gods breaks the very laws of this world. Only a select few carry the blessing in their blood. But using it all at once comes at the cost of life.

 We tap our circuits for Essence, for the strength in our legs to descend faster and faster, predicating the call to Gaffesend Base. The trail ends on the side of the long, wrapping road we tried to cut, and then it's a dead sprint.

 I refuse to be late on the first day. My sickening fear and small size propel me far ahead of the others, drawing on more anxiety than Essence as I tear past the landmarks of our small town. The trail transitions from matted dirt to concrete, to cobblestone, then back to concrete, until I'm rushing along the west edge of the lake in the military district: dragged forward by the weight of the thin breastplate; begged by my burning lungs to stop or else I might collapse into the water.

Manuscript.SevenWordSummary: They respond to the events of Firebrand.
Manuscript.Label: Fantasy World
Manuscript.Body:
I pass the threshold of the gate, gasping for breaths as my last sprint dissolves into a jog. It becomes immediately obvious that weren't the only ones to notice: most of the recruits gather outside the guard post, swarming around the re-purposed adventurers' guild like flies to excrement.

 I spot my brother Erik leaning against the doorframe.

 "What's happening?" I ask.

 "Some major Essence event."

 "Yeah, we saw it. We were on the southern hills."

 I gasp for breath. He hands me his canteen. One long drink later, I find my mouth wet enough to continue.

 "Should we be afraid?"

 "Afraid? Guards aren't supposed to be afraid," he says, staring down at me with our father's amber eyes.

 "Not afraid . . . I meant concerned," I say. My mind's too busy redirecting resources to my starving muscles, and I can feel it in the heat of my flushed face.

 "I don't think so."

 I try to slide past him to get in, but he traps me with his brazen arms. "Relax," he says. "You're going to be fine. You know I wouldn't let anything happen to you."

 "I know that," I tell him.

 "You always get so damn worked up. Just breathe," he demands. "We're safe here in the city."

 I draw several long breaths in my nose and out my mouth before he releases me, just as Bertram, Pax, and Ryder finally catch up. We enter the main room of the command post, packed to the walls with knights and soldiers. In the corner, the Line Type machines send a one-way barrage of signals across wires. There are three of them: one for the war front, one for the capital, and one that's used for up north, rarely getting an answer to anything.

 "Status of Blackwater?" Aldrin orders.

 "Clearing the line right now to get their response," a guard says.

 Loud chirps on the line screech with the strain of such distance. The vibrations resonate different-shaped keys that dance in their fixtures, stamping against a swiftly scrolling sheet of paper. A long half-minute passes, and the guard impatiently waits until there's enough information to report on.

 "Blackwater is safe," the guard says first. "A civilian event in the north district. General Ullrich sending Royal Guard to investigate, not a Mask event, full stop," he says.

 The room breathes a collective sigh of relief.

 "Was it perpetrated by Chymaeran meddling?" Aldrin asks.

 "I don't think so," he says. "I—"

 "We don't 'think' here! We speak when we know, and we know when we do," he barks.

 "Uh-Understood, sir."

 "Relay to the Valensends in the Capital. And send it to the boys at the front, so they don't have something extra to stress over tonight," he says.

 "Prompting the line," the others say, setting the mechanical keys in position.

 Aldrin turns from the command zone to address the mix of soldiers and guards. "Looks like an oddity: maybe Essence stores ignited. If it was a Divine Wish, we would know it — it surely would have done a lot more damage. I've heard some group up there called the 'Carmine' hoards dead Essence, so maybe it was them," he says.

 He turns to the guildscribes.

 "We'll run a couple scouting parties, just in case. Write up some quest forms for the new knights: this is a good excuse to get some experience and some exercise."

 The guildscribes nod before he turns to us again, waiting until all the novice knights file in through the double doors.

 "Things should die down in a week, but we're going to keep the city on alert. We want to be sure that the Chymaera aren't using this as an opportunity to strike."

 I know what he's going to ask for next when his eyes dart between the new recruits. I try to dissolve into the crowd, hoping the discomfort in my chest is just exhaustion from running across the town.

 "I need volunteers for night watch, to head north and see what's going on," he says. "It's worth a quest. Extra work means an extra day off."

 I falter when I'm shoulder-to-shoulder with my colleagues. Guilt and shame tug me forward, but that same crushing feeling I found in the cabin is so much stronger.

 "This is easy. No more than several hours," he says.

 You're all going to do this, is what I hear.

 I can only watch as my colleagues step forward, arranging themselves in groups, but I taste the smoke. I'm snared in the past. I can see the Chymaerans and their glowing, amethyst eyes as they penetrate the shattered glass windows, stretching with their sharp obsidian limbs to finish what the fire began.

 This self-immolating spite can only swell when the lust for flight outpaces fight. My hands run cold as if the Chymaeran Curse were churning in my circuits, chilling my veins, and I have to lean against the wall to catch a breath.

 Bertram follows me outside. I'm fortunate that the others are too distracted to witness this moment of utter weakness.

 "What's going on, Kat?"

 "I feel sick," I tell him.

 "Right now? All of a sudden?" He asks.

 I feel like I'm going to lose my breakfast and lunch. It's only then that he realizes he's drawing attention.

 I feel a shock pulse my body when the worst comes to pass, unable to speak or explain when Aldrin steps outside.

 "What's going on here?" Aldrin asks.

 I don't want to look weak, but maybe I should just tell him. There's no way out of this. After I think I have a grasp on my nausea, I open my mouth to speak.

 But Bertram beats me to it.

 "She's been feeling sick since the farm," he says. "They were trying to be nice with the samples and the free meal, and we were trying to be respectful: first day, you know. But after all the running..."

 "She seemed fine minutes ago," Aldrin says.

 I doubt this farce will work. I say, "No, I—"

 "Because she didn't want to look weak on the first day," Bertram says. "Don't you know how hard it is for her? She talked to me the whole way back about it, being a female guard and all, trying not to prove the stereotype."

 "Oh," Aldrin says. He approaches, placing his glove on my shoulder. "I respect that. We refuse to have that kind of backwards thinking in our ranks. We're trying to get rid of it. But you're not of use to me if you're not at your best," he says.

 I can feel the cold night air again. I manage to stand upright without the wall.

 "T-thank you," I say, wiping my mouth, although my stomach and its contents are still there.

 "Go home and get some rest: this is hardly a task, I just wanted an excuse to give you junior guards some exercise," he tells me. "And Berry—would you mind walking her home?" He hands two quest forms to him. "Bring these back to me tomorrow. I'll give you credit." And then he whispers: "Just don't tell anyone else."

 "Yes, sir. Thank you, sir," Bertram says, taking my arm before he escorts me towards the complex. We make sure to pass the gates before we drop the act.

Manuscript.SevenWordSummary: Katiya's anxiety cracks her tough facade.
Manuscript.Label: Fantasy World
Manuscript.Body:
"What was that about?" Bertram asks. The grasp of his hands on my torso is so strong that I hardly have to walk.

 "I ... I don't know," I tell him. "I thought I got over this. I thought I wasn't so damn weak and pathetic..."

 "You're not pathetic! You earned your presence here," he assures me. "You had a bad day, is all."

 "But how can I last when it's really down to the wire, when it's real, if my mind fights me at something so simple, so stupid and pathetic and weak, like this?" I let out an exasperated groan. If he wasn't holding me, I might bash myself in the face with my gauntlets.

 "We'll take it step-by-step. You have time. Space in some scouting missions between the banal tasks," he insists.

 "But that was the first step. It was a step down. It was so low that it couldn't have even been called a step, and I tripped," I tell him, feeling the tears well up in my eyes. "We went through the same thing that day, how does it not come back to haunt you? Why don't you run? Why are you so still?"

 "I don't know," he tells me, still holding me upright when all I want to do is crumble. "I just live in the absolute present. I just find that I'm less attached to it all: maybe I just don't care what happens."

 "What does that even mean?" I ask, wiping my eyes.

 "I don't know. Maybe I'm just bad at describing it," he says. "Maybe..."

 I can feel him quickly release his hands when he realizes he's holding me up by the contours of my breastplate.

 "Sorry."

 The suddenness gets me to crack a smile. It escalates further. Pretty soon we're both laughing, and I wipe the tears from my eyes.

 "But really, though. I promise that I'll always have your back. I won't go off and die on you," he says.

 "You better not," I tell him, still letting off a couple chuckles before my lungs settle. "We'll defend some more vegetables tomorrow. Maybe even something more dangerous."

 "I'll look forward to it," he says.

 There's a certain hesitation in him when he stands close, as if there's something more he wants to say. But the moment passes. Instead, he hands me my copy of the quest sheet.

 "Well," he says. "I guess I'll see you tomorrow."

 "Until tomorrow," I say.

 I wave to him as I fumble for the key in my pocket; feeling for the name etched into the iron; making sure it's still there; praying to the Gods that it won't be ground any further. There's a sweet smell of grilled meat that makes me hungry: someone cooks a pig on a spit across the way.

 Longing for rations after a long day, I turn my head to the entry window, trying to decide what I'll make. But instead, I find an odd, unflickering light illuminating the walls.

 "Huh."

 My body is out of adrenaline, so I'm strangely calm. I approach the window instead of the door, trying to remember if I latched the back window after getting free breakfast from the merchants. I press my ear to the thin, wavy glass for an auditory cue: unable to see clearly through the drawn curtains, holding my breath until I hear the words of a foreign tongue. The words lack the harshness of Chymaeran dialect. Maybe it's Ahkvasan? Auvryan or Verdalan? One of the old dialects?

 I can only make out the silhouette of a stumbling man, holding something thicker than a rapier but thinner than a sword. He doesn't seem to be taking anything. Maybe this is a test — maybe Aldrin didn't mean it and wants to see if my actions can match my claims to courage.

 I approach the front door, allowing the burgeoning anger of my incompetence to consume me, leaving no space for fear. My hand is steady, unsheathing the dagger as I gingerly turn the key in the lock until it clicks. There's no room for explanation that this isn't a test or a burglar, so I let the Essence saturate my circuits.

 I turn the handle and rush the intruder. I spring forward with such force that the floorboards nearly snap when they give. My circuits run hot with Essence. My hands glow orange with heat, ready to burn their flesh until they beg to be sent to the Reservoir of Souls.

 But just before I'm ready to deal his death, he turns to face me, and I'm unable to reconcile the oddness of his appearance.

 The man looks no older than I am, somewhere halfway mixed between a Royal and a vagrant. The fineness of his silken shirt is accented with a checkered pattern of light blue boxes. The fabric is whiter than snow. His stubble is unkempt and shaggy though his light brown hair is clipped finer than all the royals I've ever seen. His brown eyes widen with panic as I intercept him, casting him over the kitchen table, searing the fabric of his fine shirt with fire before I can withdraw the heat from my hands.

 He drops the strange sword against the ground, and it looks like a metal training stick that ends with a basket, not even a blade. Is it a broom? Is he some kind of housekeeper hired by the Royal Guard, another service like the knocker?

 He's far too weak to put up a fight when I straddle him against the floor, his face smudged in the puddle of porridge I left when I was rushing out the door. He's so weak that I have to lighten my grasp or else I might break his bones.

 It's then that he spills his first string of words to me. And somehow, I understand them perfectly.
